title: Subdomain takeover on dev-admin.periscope.tv

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
Subdomain takeover on dev-admin.periscope.tv
I takeover the subdomain and upload the index file : index.html

## Impact

Subdomain takeover on dev-admin.periscope.tv
Subdomain takeover on dev-admin.periscope.tv/index.html
http://dev-admin.periscope.tv.s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/index.html
vulnerability_information_html:
Subdomain takeover on dev-admin.periscope.tv
I takeover the subdomain and upload the index file : index.html

Impact

Subdomain takeover on dev-admin.periscope.tv
Subdomain takeover on dev-admin.periscope.tv/index.html
http://dev-admin.periscope.tv.s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/index.html

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @h1ch3ro

It looks like you claimed an AWS subdomain, not a Twitter subdomain. When we navigate to the domain `http://dev-admin.periscope.tv/index.html` we receive no response. The URL `http://dev-admin.periscope.tv.s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/index.html` contains a Twitter subdomain, but it is actually part of AWS's root domain `s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com`. Can you provide any more evidence to demonstrate that Twitter owns the AWS domain in your report?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report @h1ch3ro

It looks like you claimed an AWS subdomain, not a Twitter subdomain. When we navigate to the domain http://dev-admin.periscope.tv/index.html we receive no response. The URL http://dev-admin.periscope.tv.s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/index.html contains a Twitter subdomain, but it is actually part of AWS's root domain s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com. Can you provide any more evidence to demonstrate that Twitter owns the AWS domain in your report?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Thank you for your response @h1ch3ro.

In this case, the DNS record associated with `dev-admin.periscope.tv` is deleted so it should not be possible to take over this subdomain. It is possible that during the normal upkeep of the site, something was changed that corrected the issue you were seeing, however, I can assure you that this was not as a result of this report. As neither of us can reproduce the issue at this time, we have no choice but to close this report, but please let us know if you encounter it again and we can reopen this. We'll close as Informative to preserve your reputation.


Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your response @h1ch3ro.

In this case, the DNS record associated with dev-admin.periscope.tv is deleted so it should not be possible to take over this subdomain. It is possible that during the normal upkeep of the site, something was changed that corrected the issue you were seeing, however, I can assure you that this was not as a result of this report. As neither of us can reproduce the issue at this time, we have no choice but to close this report, but please let us know if you encounter it again and we can reopen this. We'll close as Informative to preserve your reputation.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Can you answer us the following questions @h1ch3ro?
1. Did you create the S3 bucket, http://dev-admin.periscope.tv.s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/index.html, on AWS?  
2. Did you set up logging on your cloud front instance? F464895

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Hi h1ch3ro,

I'm sorry for the confusion about this report. I took a look into this report, and have determined that the resolution of this issue was unrelated to your report. As a result, we won't be rewarding a bounty for this issue. However, since you are reporting something that appears to have been valid at the time it was reported, I'm going to keep this closed as "Resolved" so that you get the reputation points. You'll see an update about the bounty eligibility shortly.

Sorry for the rather confusing timeline on this report. Thanks for thinking of Twitter security!
